dual_autodiff package

Submodules

dual_autodiff.dual module

class Dual(real, dual)[source]

Bases: object

A class representing dual numbers for automatic differentiation.

real

The real part of the dual number. This can be a scalar (float or int) or an array-like object (e.g., list, tuple, numpy.ndarray).

Type:

float, int, or array-like

dual

The dual part of the dual number. This can be a scalar (float or int) or an array-like object (e.g., list, tuple, numpy.ndarray).

Type:

float, int, or array-like

Note

For mathematical operations like sine, cosine, and logarithm, the real and dual parts of the output are evaluated according to the following formula:

\[f(a + b\epsilon) = f(a) + f'(a)b\epsilon\]

This formula describes how dual numbers are processed through a given mathematical function (f).

Initialize an object of the Dual class.

Parameters:

  • real (float, int, or array-like) – The real part of the dual number. This can be a scalar or an array-like object.

  • dual (float, int, or array-like) – The dual part of the dual number. This can be a scalar or an array-like object.

Raises:

ValueError – If both real and dual are arrays (e.g., numpy.ndarray) but their shapes do not match.

Note

If both real and dual are arrays, a check is performed to ensure their shapes match. This is to ensure that element-wise operations on the dual number are valid. If the shapes are mismatched, a ValueError is raised.

__add__(other)[source]

Add two Dual numbers.

Operator:

Uses the \(+\) operator.

Returns:

A new Dual number representing their sum.

Return type:

Dual

__mul__(other)[source]

Multiply two Dual numbers.

Operator:

Uses the \(*\) operator.

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the product \((a + b\epsilon)(c + d\epsilon)\). The real part of the product output is simply the product of the real parts of the arguments \(ab\). The dual part of the output is the term that is first order in \(\epsilon\) \((ad + bc)\).

Return type:

Dual

__pow__(exponent)[source]

Raise a Dual number to a power.

Operator:

Uses the \(**\) operator.

Parameters:

exponent (float, int) – The exponent to raise the Dual number to. Must be a real number.

Returns:

A new Dual number raised to the power of the exponent.

Return type:

Dual

__sub__(other)[source]

Subtract one Dual number from another.

Operator:

Uses the \(-\) operator.

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the difference.

Return type:

Dual

Note

For addition and subtraction, the real and dual parts are added or subtracted separately.

cos()[source]

Compute the cosine of the Dual number.

Inputs:

scalar, array-like

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the cosine.

Return type:

Dual

exp()[source]

Compute the exponential of the Dual number.

Inputs:

scalar, array-like

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the exponential.

Return type:

Dual

log()[source]

Compute the natural logarithm of the Dual number.

Inputs:

scalar, array-like

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the natural logarithm.

Return type:

Dual

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the real part is less than or equal to zero.

  • ValueError – If the real part is less than 1e-10.

  • RuntimeWarning – If the real part is close to zero within 1e-6 but larger than 1e-10, to warn of potential numerical instability.

sin()[source]

Compute the sine of the Dual number.

Inputs:

scalar, array-like

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the sine.

Return type:

Dual

tan()[source]

Compute the tangent of the Dual number.

Inputs:

scalar, array-like

Returns:

A new Dual number representing the tangent.

Return type:

Dual

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the real part is within 1e-10 of (π/2 + nπ), where tangent is undefined.

  • RuntimeWarning – If the real part is close to (π/2 + nπ) by less than 1e-6, which may cause numerical instability.
